articles.author: Samia Nakhoul, Maya Gebeily, Parisa Hafezi, Suleiman Al-Khalidi
articles.description: Bashar al-Assad confided in almost no one about his plans to flee Syria as his reign collapsed. Instead, aides, officials and even relatives were deceived or kept in the dark, more than a dozen people with knowledge of the events told Reuters.
articles.title: Insight: Assad's final hours in Syria: Deception, despair and flight

articles.author: Dominique Vidalon, Sudip Kar-Gupta
articles.description: French President Emmanuel Macron named Francois Bayrou as his fourth prime minister of 2024 on Friday, charging the veteran centrist with steering the country out of its second political crisis in the past six months.
articles.title: France's Macron names veteran centrist ally Bayrou as prime minister

articles.author: Dan Peleschuk
articles.description: The new commander of Ukraine's ground forces plans a "massive transformation" of his branch to improve troop training, management and recruitment, Kyiv said on Friday, as it grapples with manpower problems at the front.
articles.title: Ukrainian general to overhaul training, management amid manpower woes

articles.author: Olga Popova, Gleb Stolyarov, Jonathan Saul
articles.description: Russian wheat supplies to Syria have been suspended because of uncertainty about the new government and payment delays, Russian and Syrian sources said on Friday, while two vessels carrying Russian wheat for Syria did not reach their destinations.
articles.title: Exclusive: Russian grain exports to Syria suspended due to uncertainty

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: South Korean opposition leader Lee Jae-myung said on Friday the best way to restore order in the country is to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol, a day ahead of a planned parliamentary vote over Yoon's short-lived imposition of martial law.
articles.title: South Korea opposition leader Lee says impeaching Yoon best way to restore order

articles.author: Nidal Al-Mughrabi
articles.description: At least 35 Palestinians were killed early on Thursday in Israeli bombings of various areas in the Gaza Strip, the Palestinian news agency WAFA reported.
articles.title: Israeli strikes on Gaza kill 35 Palestinians on Thursday, Palestinian news agency reports

articles.author: Laila Bassam, John Davison, Maggie Michael, Tuvan Gumrukcu
articles.description: Tens of thousands of Syrians, mostly Shi'ite Muslims, have fled to Lebanon since Sunni Muslim Islamists toppled Bashar al-Assad, fearing persecution despite assurances from the new rulers in Damascus that they will be safe, a Lebanese official said.
articles.title: Syrian Shi'ites and other minorities flee to Lebanon, fearing Islamist rule

articles.author: Francois Murphy
articles.description: Austria's conservative-led government said on Friday it is offering Syrian refugees a "return bonus" of 1,000 euros ($1,050) to move back to their home country after the fall of Bashar al-Assad.
articles.title: Austria offers Syrian refugees 1,000 euros to return home

articles.author: Andreas Rinke, Rachel More
articles.description: Drones were spotted flying over the U.S. air base at Ramstein in Germany in early December, a spokesperson for the U.S. Air Force said on Friday.
articles.title: U.S. military confirms drone sightings at air base in Germany

articles.author: Michael Martina, David Brunnstrom
articles.description: The United States and China signed a renewed science cooperation agreement on Friday, the State Department said, this time with "robust national security guardrails," despite objections from Republicans who argue the decision should have been left to the incoming Trump administration.
articles.title: Biden administration inks new science cooperation deal with China; Republicans cry foul
